values:
I'm alive.  With any luck, Chad will get into U of Arizona and all will be good.

I've been selling our books and random crap on Amazon because etsy bites.  Amazon also doesn't make you pay up front for listing things, but there are some restrictions and the fees you do pay kinda bites at the end.

I have an appointment tomorrow to talk to a doc about sleep apnea.  Have a followup on the abnormal pap smear/biopsy sometime in the next month.  Still waiting for another doc to call me back for the appointment for adhd.  blah.

Maybe I'll start exercising again once my back stop hurting.  That would be a good idea.  I also need to clean my work area up and do some more work!

 me:  smoooch
aww
your smooch is longer than my smooch
 me:  *feeds the smooch an enhancement pill *
 Chad:  haha
 me:  smoooooooooooo ooooooooooooooooo ooooooooooooooooooch

 me:  oh no, it broke!

http://www.boingboing.net/2008/12/11/scientists-extract-i.html

OMGFUCKYEAH!  I've been hoping someone would figure that out!  I want to record my dreams and show people just how fucking weird they are.  Not quite the same as what's going on in this research, but it's a major step in the direction I want to see somebody going in.

Everyone who flies knows that airport food is terrible and sometimes even stale, but hunger is amazingly good at making you do crazy things.  I had enough foresight to bring a snack of my favorite Anna's ginger thin cookies and some cheese so that I wouldn't have to buy the overpriced, salt encrusted junk they sell on planes nowadays in lieu of food, but didn't have time to pack a bento for us like I'd originally planned to do.  And so, mad with hunger, I grabbed a burger at the Burger King at MKE.  I wasn't expecting it to be good, but I did expect them not to short me the one meat patty that was supposed to be in there.  I'd heard that the meat in burgers had withered into rather thin corn-filled wafers over the years, but not that it had shrunken to the point of nonexistence.  Over $3 for a bun with a smattering of toppings?  Ridiculous doesn't even begin to describe it.

Still, this is nothing compared to the bullshit the TSA puts us through.  I've had them demand that I let them X-ray an empty water bottle after I downed the contents right in front of them.  It's not like you could hide much in the small bit of opaque plastic cap. I'm not sure when they decided that shoes could not be placed in the plastic bins (but is ok for other stuff?), or if the ones at MKE are particularly stupid, but they moved mine without telling me and left the laces dangling.  It got caught on the rollers and as I tried to free them, more stuff came up and smashed into the boots.  I've had the boots for years so I'm not afraid of a few scuff marks, but I do want to prevent them from being unnecessarily trashed.  The bin with my laptop rolled out over the laces and as I tried to move it all, more stuff smashed out, this time flipping the bin with my laptop.  The woman working for the TSA LAUGHED at me and said "You just flipped your computer out!"  I wanted to say "Bitch, fuck you.  I'm not blind and I really don't appreciate you laughing at my misfortunes." but I didn't want them to haul me into some room and beat me.

Now that my departure for California is just around the corner, I'm wishing I had a few more days to work on crap here.  

When I read Howl's Moving Castle as a kid, I loved the idea of being able to turn a dial on a door and open it to a different city whenever I wanted to.  Now, to get to California, I have to let the TSA rifle through my things.  I'm certainly not driving over 2000 miles and Amtrak's website pissed me off.  Greyhound takes a few days but I've never taken it so I don't know how good or bad it is.

Back to packing I go.

I've been posting stuff on http://blog.blagofaire.com

Go read my haikus and stuff!  The goal is to post one a day, or something else amusing.
I'm planning on making something out of those gift card holders available at Starbucks, so snag a handful for me!  I'll be in the bay area on the 11th and in Davis at some point after that.

I'm alive.  That's how I often answer the question, "How are you?"  It doesn't mean much, but the question doesn't really seem to mean much either.

Editing long papers is mindnumbingly boring.  I don't know how people do this for a living.

I have brightkite.com updating twitter.  Let me know if you want an invite.

I'm not surprised, but I do have odd hobbies.

I now have 23.67 Euro in paypal.  How should I spend it?  It's roughly $30 USD, but I'm hoping to exchange it when the rate is better if I don't buy anything with it.  

*sigh* This is what I get for doing international business.

I has precancer.  Wish me luck or pray for me or rattle some chicken bones or whatever you folks do.

In my search for info, I came across this:
Vitamin Supplements May Increase Breast Cancer

Multivitamin-multimineral supplement use and mammographic breast density by Sylvie Bérubé in the May 2008 issue of the American Journal of Clinical Nutrition reported that, “Regular multivitamin-multimineral supplement use was found to be associated with higher mean breast density among premenopausal women…Because breast density is strongly and positively related to breast cancer risk, these findings do not support any benefit from multivitamin-multimineral supplement use on breast cancer risk. Instead, they suggest that such multivitamin-multimineral supplement use should be studied for its possible association with an increased risk of breast cancer.”1

Comment:

Taking various vitamin supplements, like beta-carotene, vitamin E, and/or folic acid has been found in multiple studies to increase the risk of cancer, heart disease, and overall death.2 Many observational studies have found that a high intake of fruits and vegetables, which are also filled with antioxidant, folic acid, and other vitamins, is associated with a decreased risk of cancer. Foods are not the same as supplements. When isolated, concentrated nutrients are ingested, as with multivitamin and multimineral supplements, chemical imbalances are created within the cells—the end result, as many studies have shown, is an increased risk of disease and earlier death.2

More than half of the women in the US take supplements; therefore, even a small percentage increase in illness will mean many people are affected. People should be getting their nutrients in their original packages—starches, vegetables, and fruits. Supplements should be considered medicines, at best, and should carry appropriate warnings on their labels, at least.

1) Bérubé S, Diorio C, Brisson J. Multivitamin-multimineral supplement use and mammographic breast density. Am J Clin Nutr. 2008 May;87(5):1400-4.

2) Bjelakovic G, Nikolova D, Simonetti RG, Gluud C. Antioxidant supplements for prevention of mortality in healthy participants and patients with various diseases. Cochrane Database Syst Rev. 2008 Apr 16;(2):CD007176.

http://www.drmcdougall.com/misc/2008nl/may/fav5.htm

So maybe I'll continue to forget to take it now and then?
How about steampunk genius robot ninja pirate monkey?
Ok, so this set of tests came back normal.  Still not sure what's wrong with me and my back has hurting a LOT but at least I'll probably not die of brain cancer any time soon.  Party?

Well, it took me quite a while, but I have lost about 20 pounds and counting.  I fit into some of those belts now.  Yay!  I don't really feel skinnier though.

I am horrendously allergic to dust mites and certain grasses, according to the allergy test done the other day.  Minor allergies to dogs, cats, a bit to feathers, hamsters, etc.  The swollen red blobs on my back from the test are more or less gone now.  I moved everything out of the bedroom, found the scifi DVDs, stacked the mattresses, mopped, threw some stuff in the washing machine, moved the coffee table and night stand in, mopped again, washed other stuff, called grandma and chatted for half an hour while doing other stuff, ate tuna with mung beans and rice with homemade pickled ginger (feel that antiseptic/good-for-you BURN!), made a garbage can for the bedroom, moved some stuff, scrubbed the sink, scrubbed the bathtub, swept the kitchen, washed other things, and a bajillion other things I forgot.  It's only 4:30 now and my day is FAR from over.
Another doc's visit today.  And I have to take two buses to get there, which is over an hour either way, and it might storm later.  Fun.

I'm mailing 5 items tomorrow.  Yay!
I'm having pancakes with friends tomorrow.  Yay!
I'm seeing the gyne tomorrow.  Yay?
I'm going to a party tomorrow.  Yay!

Maybe I should write my mom.

According to the interwubs, giraffe males and females feed on different parts of a tree.  The males munch the upper part and the females on the lower, which ensures that both groups get to munch without having to compete for food with each other.  Long story short, well fed animals make more babies.

Those nubs on giraffes are called "ossicones".  More info:

http://whitesouse.blogspot.com/2007/05/why-do-giraffes-have-horns.html

Mushroom pate made with pork, though not exactly low sodium or veg friendly, is OMFG delicious on my OMFG homemade cheesy bread, which is also not very low on sodium after all.  Damn you, asiago!

Things I've learned:

Asiago is higher in sodium, which probably contributed to the less-than-expected levels of rising.  Not sure what else it would have been.  

Shredded cheese disappears into the bread and adds some cheesy taste, but I'll probably have to chunk the cheese if I want to see any actual cheesy bits in the bread.  This may or may not help the rising.  After I'm done with this bit of asiago, I doubt I'll be getting more any time soon.  Goodbye, salty goodness!

Cutting back on sodium is hard when you didn't have all that much to begin with and some things are just SO tasty.  

I have Chinese sausage and salami.  I might throw them into the bread next time and skip the salt and butter that I'm out of anyway.  I wonder how well spinach would go with them...

It takes me at least a week to eat a loaf of bread if I'm eating some every day.  There are settings in my bread maker for a smaller loaf so I may go with that.  Might bake more evenly, too.  I aim to use up all of the jar of yeast before we move next year so I don't have to toss it out.  Might sell the breadmaker before we move, too, but not before the end of winter because I'm putting it and any toaster I get in the bedroom!

My mom was in the hospital again.  Her knee is fucked up and they don't know why so they did a ton of scans.  

There is no god.

Cheese is a strange thing to me because I'm Asian and mildly lactose intolerant.  It's not going to kill me and I like trying new things so here's info on one I randomly picked up today.  It was a teeny little piece but more than enough for me to sniff and taste... and never buy ever again.  Not that I hate it or anything, but it's none too special for its price per pound, which is silly given that it started as leftover cheese.  Now to figure out what to do with the rest of the wee slice...  


From http://www.cheesemonthclub.com/pastnewsletters/vol5no3.htm:

Morbier


Morbier Du Livradois comes to us in a fourteen pound wheel. We cut and wrap it in special papers to preserve the flavor and allow the cheese to breath this is very important for storing most cheeses.This European delight is made from raw cow's milk from the Savoie region in France, adding depth to the flavor and giving it a sweet taste and the smell of fresh hay. Aptly named (the word Morbier means "small market town"), Morbier was originally made by cheesemakers who lived in the village of Morez in the Jura Mountains of France. Situated in a deep valley, a few miles from the Swiss border, Morez is now surrounded by ski resorts - Les Rouss
Morbier Du Livradois comes to us in a fourteen pound wheel. We cut and wrap it in special papers to preserve the flavor and allow the cheese to breath this is very important for storing most cheeses.es, Prémanon, Morbier, Bellefontaine, etc.

About two hundred years ago when Morbier was first made, the cheese-makers used left over curd from Comte production - Morbier was made strictly for the cheesemakers consumption. The look of this AOC cheese is quite distinctive with a horizontal gray-black line running through the middle of it. This "line" is actually a mixture of edible vegetable ash. The cheesemaker would press the leftover curd from the evening's production of Comte into a round mold and cover that curd with a thin layer of ash to prevent it from drying out. The next day he pressed the leftover morning curd on top of the ash. (Yes, cows need to be milked twice a day!) You could tell which layer of the cheese came from the evening milking, since it tastes fruitier than that from the morning milking.
There are lots of stories about how that ash became part of this cheese. One that sounds plausible is that the curd was left to sit by the fire overnight until the morning milking, and the ash from the fire blew on to the settling Curd. Others say soot from the bottom of the kettles was intentionally rubbed on the evening layer to keep it from drying. Our favorite story is that a clumsy cheesemaker dropped a freshly made cheese… and to hide the soiled side, he placed another layer on top. Traditionally, a half wheel of Morbier would be propped up by the fire. As it started to melt, the cheese would be scraped on to crusty bread or hot potatoes. As the tradition suggests, Morbier is a wonderful cheese for melting! Bon appetit!


The Auvergne where both Morbier and Cantal originated, lies in the heart of the Massif Central, a mountain range with a chain of long extinct volcanoes, or "Puy." The Allier is rich farm country with gentle hills and huge forests. The landscape of the Puy-de-Dome and Cantal highlands changes into sweeping glacier valleys, lakes, waterfalls and wide plateaux. There you will find unspoiled Medieval towns and mountain villages. And in the wilds of the Livradois, remote stone and slate roofed "jasseries, burons, or actives" - ancient summer farmhouses on the plateaux. As you might expect, the people here are warm and friendly.

Much of the flora and fauna common in the wilder parts of France are not found in other parts of Europe. You will see many varieties of wild orchids (e.g. the elderflower, pyramidal, and marsh), the spring anemone, wild pansies and narcissi, maiden pinks, and the great yellow gentian. Clover, all sorts of wild-flowers, and wild onions are some of plants the cows feast on, and what a cow eats really does flavor the milk they produce, and the resulting cheeses. It's kind of like adding fresh fruit to make a milk shake, but this way it's added before the cow is milked. A charming place to visit - from spring until late autumn, there are country fetes held to celebrate the harvest and the movement of the herds to and from their mountain pastures. And you will find numerous markets where you can trawl through piles of bric-a-brac.


Tasting Notes

This AOC cheese is uncooked, pressed, and allowed to mature for two months, then it is brushed with brime and allowed to age at least another two months. During the maturing period, Morbier develops a natural fine creamy-brown crust or rind. At maturity it is semi-soft, yet firm, and has a complex fruity flavor with a slight zing sophisticated, yet liked by many. The ivory-yellow pâte is often described as supple, springy, and silky when touched - dry and sticky at the same time. Not only serving as a divide, the vegetable ash separating the cheese layers makes an aesthetic, dramatic presentation and has a complex, bold flavor. Mobier is a cheese that can steal the show when it comes to cheese platters. Companion wines include light fruity reds, Arbois red or white, Pouilly sur Loire, and tangy white wines like Muscadet and Sancerre.
FYI - AOC: About 40 cheeses in France, including Mobier and Cantal, have been awarded The Appellation d'Origine Controlee. This designation guarantees that the cheeses have been produced within a specified province, region, and commune, follows traditional recipes and production methods, monitors affinage (maturity), and maintains the highest prescribed standards.

I'm using some really nice, soft fabric for the new llamas but the machine doesn't like it and the stitches don't catch on the underside, which means they come right off.I tried to make this one poofier than before, which means it's even harder to sew.  I got it to stitch by putting a sheet of paper in between the two layers or under, but it's still a pain to do!

Oh well, have to go to a meeting now.  Be nice if I had a bike...

OMFG it's so cute! I want one that looks like that but has no vocal cords because I hate high pitched, yappy things. And when it's that small, you know it has to be high pitched. I saw a lady with two little ones on leashes and was tempted to jump off the bus to go OMGSQUEEEEEEEEEE!!!

I made a silly ring that is now on etsy:

I now have an electric guitar.  It needs new strings and all that jazz, but it's a free guitar.  I wanted a bike, but I suppose this will do for now :D  It even came with a "viva Zapata" sticker!  I'm not sure what caused the discoloration and warping of the pickguard but aside from a few dings and a broken string, the rest of it looks fine.

Fruit flies attacked my baguette. I was going to eat that, you little fuckers!  Now there's just sliced bread and I KNOW you little bastards are eyeing that because I see you hovering over it!  Graaaaaa!

Gone are the flappers and speakeasies, the shingle bobs and the sea of cloches, but the houses with their teeny little back balconies remain.  What were they for?  Airing out the stairway?  Making decrees at the trees in the back yard?  Or was it an easy dock for the airship of Adventure?

*cue the music*

So there's a name for this... I feel totally weak after being tickled or laughing too much sometimes.  I try to show Chad by squeezing his arm as hard as I can and he just looks at me funny.  On the very rare occasion, I have trouble holding things because I can't get my fingers to close around something tight enough.  Suck!  But it doesn't last too long and isn't so bad that I can't just deal with it and do squeeze tests while waiting for my strength to return.  (I will crush you, little styrofoam cup!!  Just you wait!!  Huuuuurgh!  Just you wait some more!)  

I assume this has something to do with how sensitive my skin is, which makes it easier to flood and overload whatever part of the noggin' handles that sort of thing and fails to ignore most of it like most people's do.  I occasionally go "OMG! Texture! Mmm......"  

I guess I'm weirder than I thought.

Normal kids have hobbies like stamp collecting or sports. I spent my time as a kid at the library reading about birds and everything I could find about them, including their reproduction and diseases. Because of this, I know far more about eggs than any person who doesn't work with birds should ever need to know. The hubbie loves eating eggs and feels bad for the chickens so he buys only cage free egg$, which are supposed to be more humane than regular, cheaper eggs. I aim to inform you that this is not necessarily the case, that the chickens are not necessarily better off and these eggs are inferior to regular eggs even though they can cost several times more. We have a few dozen eggs in the fridge, all "cage free". The size and shape of the eggs are irregular, and many of the eggs themselves have a "wobbly" appearance. A quick search found half a dozen cracked and some badly broken, whites oozing out. The worst ones were scaly, with numerous visible pits and bumps or "pimples". One had a mysterious yellowish area on the shell, not caused by direct contact with the broken egg sitting diagonally from it, as the spot was on top. A site for reference: http://www.thepoultrysite.com/ourbooks/1/egg-quality-handbook/ These problems can be caused by stress, poor nutrition, crowding, age, and/or disease. I took these photos at about 5:30 AM, so the only lighting was what came with the kitchen. Behold the nastiness: There are a few more on flickr.

http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2002/aug/09/gender.uk

"When a man foots the bill, is it just a harmless act of generosity - or is something more insidious going on? Ann Marlowe explains why she will always go Dutch. Below, Horatio Clare defends his right to pay"

"My interest in money, and my pride in making it, were very new. I had gone through Harvard planning to become a philosophy professor. But to my surprise and dismay, I was bored silly. I also felt trapped financially as never before. Grad school meant not just classes, but ugly wallpaper, furniture from the street that I could not afford to replace, and a cheap apartment. It was years before I could eat squid ($3 for a 5lb frozen block) or liver (60 cents a pound) again.

By the end of the spring semester, I had lost interest in teaching philosophy: I knew I would go mad if I had to spend the next five years like this. The only ambition that made sense to me was to become rich. I passionately wanted to be able to say that I was successful, even if it was just to myself that I said it. Money was a good thing, I knew with the unshakable conviction of one for whom it had been short. But the status that money provided was an even better thing."

The thing was a self replicating 3-D printer, just like its mommy.  How awesome is that?  It melted plastic and made whatever you programmed it to make because it LOVED you and wanted you to have silly plastic doorknobs an' shit.  But no, the TSA murdered it!

On the return journey from OSCON, baggage handling found themselves outclassed. Instead of simply smacking the box around a few times as had happened on the outbound trip, the TSA dismantled the custom hard-case for the RepRap by removing the 16 bolts securing the top panel rather than undoing the 8 bolts marked "Open".

Unable to fit the panel back on again - it was not meant to come off so the nuts were not captive - they simply sent it on its way with the panel detached. I retrieved it from the conveyor - as opposed from the fragile/outsize section despite clear "Fragile" stickers on every face...

http://blog.reprap.org/2008/07/tsa-really-wreck-reprap-child.html

Another reason why people hate the US.  *sigh*
I find it rather unfortunate that myfullname.com has been taken by an idiot with no web design skills.  I need to come up with something nifty for a website now.  *sigh*

I have some hilarious instant coffee with instructions in English and Russian.  Prince of Peace coffee also has a ginormous American flag and eagle on top... made in Singapore.  I also have coffee grounds from Vietnam that will help you with "confidence in your existence."  How awesome is that?  I was totally having an existential moment!
Some live to the beat of a different drum; I fired the drummer and hired a crew of blindfolded mimes.

so how do u say hi on this thing, whatdo u like more (WHATS GOING OOON)...(how r u doing this morning mama)...(HOMIE WHATS HAPPENING) or a akwored....hi...............


WTF people, WTF?


Unrelated: I had another dream last night in which I was flipping through a book with a ton of awesome information and answers to all the questions I'd ever want answered.  I kept going OOO, I want to read that section!  And this section!  And this one!  One explained  the physical brain and thoughts, which as far as I know, is not something we completely understand yet.  It also went into brains figuring out puzzles and security problems.  It's like the encyclopedia for kids I had when I was a kid and thought was totally awesome, only much more ginormous and so much more... orgasmically delicious.  I'm always sad when I wake up from dreams in which I find a book with awesometastic knowledge and can't bring it out of the dream.  It looked like your typical modern bio textbook on the inside, at least, from what I remember of the parts I looked at, but the outside was... different, like it kept fading in and out of existence.  The dimensions of the book also kept changing.  I was in a fairly well lit, sizeable  room, possibly in a library.

*sigh* I had the secrets of the universe in my hands again and it slipped right back out...

I was playing Pandemic 2 (or waiting to rack up mutation points really) when I thought I may as well look up lupus. According to wikipedia:

Survival in patients with SLE in the United States, Canada, and Europe is approximately 95% at 5 years, 90% at 10 years, and 78% at 20 years.

Well... that still sucks.  I'll make an appointment with my doctor when I get back.  He prescribed some cream last time for the rashes but I'd feel better if we had some tests done.  THIS is why it's great to have health insurance.  I'm SO itchy.   I think Islamic clothing might be a good idea if it weren't for all the crazy fucks that might give me shit for it.  In a perfect world, I wouldn't need clothing but noooooo, I have to live in reality!  Bah! 

My ginormous umbrella and hat are over 2000 miles away :(

I banged my knee on a custom bed frame my uncles made that stuck out farther than I thought it did and it's still a bit bruised and achy.

This game amuses me:

http://www.crazymonkeygames.com/Pandemic-2.html

You basically control the evolution of a disease that can destroy the world!  Muaahahahahahah!
